Since Sections 34*83 and 34*84 of the Postal Regulations stem from the
foregoing legislation and are a codification of this legislation, any
desired changes would have to bo brought about by further legislation
and cannot be accomplished by merely requesting the Post Office to change
its regulations ■=— or the Interstate Commerce Comission to enlarge the
scope of the parcel post zones. In this connection, it may be of interest
to you to know that the Postmaster General and the Bureau of the Budget
opposed the enactment of Public Law 141 because of the resulting reduction
in revenues and its adverse effect upon the continuing postal deficit.
The Congress, however, from their report felt strongly that the benefits
to be derived from the "widest possible dissemination of information both
educational and cultural purposes is essential to our national welfare,"
and outweighed the considerations presented by the Postmaster General
and the Bureau of the Budget.
Although additional legislation would be necessary to correct the dis~
criminatory effects of tha new postal rates upon NAEB tape recordings,
you of course realise that the tax-exempt status of MSB precludes it
from lobbying. This prohibition, however, does not extend to the
individual members of MSB.
I hope you will find the foregoing information helpful, and that you will
let ms know if there is anything else I can do.
